ygData.subject: Re: out of memory error
ygData.msgSnippet: Reuben, I don t know if Ugo is still reading this group so he may have more technical insight into the memory usage since he wrote JNEAT, but here are a few

Reuben,

I don't know if Ugo is still reading this group so he may have more 
technical insight into the memory usage since he wrote JNEAT, but 
here are a few ideas:

-It may just be that the population is taking up too much room with 
big genomes.  You can try reducing the population size.  It really 
doesn't have to be big to be effective.  Just remember that the 
number of species should be roughly popsize/12. 

-See the question on the NEAT Users Page FAQ: 
 "NEAT takes up too much memory. Can I save memory somehow? "
It is aimed at my C++ code but I think the same principle can 
probably be applied in JNEAT.

-Use a memory monitor and figure out exactly when the memory is 
overflowing.  Is it right when the pop is created or does it 
gradually build up over generations?

-Try a computer with more memory.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Reuben Grinberg <reuben.grinberg@y...> 
wrote:
> Hey Guys,
> 
> I'm using jNeat and I just modified the code so I could do 
> pole-balacing. It works fine, and now I'm trying to use image 
input. 
> Right now the input is small-ish - 30 x 50 = 1500. I generated one 
> random genome, and am using that as the starting genome file. Now 
I'm 
> getting OutOfMemory errors. Any suggestions?
> 
> Thanks,
> Reuben
